head.supplied: Monga ¶ 17/7/90. ¶ ¶ […] ¶ ¶ Re the Eucalypt of which I forwarded fruiting specimens, I beg to inform you that I traced the tree, and found that it is not the White Ash like looking tree, I suspecte...

div.p: MRS 203/2, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921, 90/414 Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney

Re the Eucalypt of which I forwarded fruiting specimens, I beg to inform you that I traced the tree, and found that it is not the White Ash like looking tree, I suspected the fruit to nalis. […] between a Messmate and a Stringybark […]I am just making up a set of specimens to send to Baron von Muller, as complete as it can be at present, that means, fruit, bud, and young state leaves, but no flowers.[…]

Baron von Muller has sent me the reprint with plates of Euc. Maideni. I think the plates are very well done. You will no doubt be pleased to learn that the redflowering Eriostemon proved to be new, as I always said it would, and the Baron has under his and my own name conjointly, dedicated it to Mr. Carruthers
then or later Premier and minister for Public Instruction. I am very glad, for I never liked the idea of having it named after Mr . Combes.
or similar spelling; the three ridges between the o and the b could represent several letters. Helen Y thinks that an Edward Combes accompanied Liversidge in an investigation of Technological Museums in Europe c1880. It will be published in the August number of the Victorian "Field Naturalists Club". In a sort of apologetic way the Baron says, it was easier for him to have it published in Victoria than in N.S.W. especially as he at the same time has two or three new Salsolaceae to describe. […]
